title: 108_hr4019
content: The text chunk "CONCERNING THE PARTICIPATION OF TAIWAN IN THE WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION" is about Taiwan's involvement in the WHO. Congress recognizes the importance of good health and access to high-quality health information and services for public health improvement. They highlight the benefits of Taiwan's participation in international health cooperation forums, given its significant population and achievements in the health field. Taiwan has achieved high life expectancy levels and low maternal and infant mortality rates, eradicated infectious diseases like cholera and smallpox, and collaborated closely with the US Centers for Disease Control. They have also provided hepatitis B vaccinations and expressed willingness to assist in international aid. On January 14, 2001, Taiwan sent rescue teams and donated $200,000 in relief aid to El Salvador after an earthquake. Taiwan has also participated as observers in the World Health Assembly, along with other organizations like the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Order of Malta. The United States declared support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations, specifically the WHO, in 1994. Public Law 106-137 mandated a report on efforts to support Taiwan's involvement in the WHO. President Bush emphasized the importance of Taiwan's participation in the WHO for global health in 2001. President Bush and Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson expressed support for Taiwan's participation in the WHO, emphasizing the importance of Taiwan's voice being heard in international organizations. They focused on finding ways for Taiwan to benefit and contribute to the WHO, including gaining observership status at the World Health Assembly. Taiwan supports global health efforts by donating $1,000,000 to fight HIV/AIDS. In 2003, Taiwan faced 84 deaths from SARS and is currently dealing with the reemergence of bird flu in Asia. The reemergence of influenza strains in Asia, reported by multiple countries, highlights the importance of global health cooperation and access to organizations like the WHO. The Secretary of Health and Human Services emphasized the need for effective public health for all peoples. Taiwan's support for global health includes a $1,000,000 donation to fight HIV/AIDS. The Secretary of State is authorized to endorse and obtain observer status for Taiwan at the World Health Assembly summit in Geneva. A report on the plan must be submitted to Congress annually. The Secretary of State is required to submit an annual report to Congress detailing the United States' plan to support Taiwan's bid for observer status at the World Health Assembly summit in Geneva. The report must include efforts made to promote Taiwan's bid and steps to be taken at the next meeting. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 21, 2004.
